docs.title: About COST
docs.text:
COST (European Cooperation in Science and Technology) is a funding agency for research and innovation networks. COST Actions help connect research initiatives across Europe and beyond, enabling scientists to grow their ideas by sharing them with their peers.

**COST Action CA19130** | Funded by the European Union | 2020-2024 [COST Website](https://www.cost.eu/actions/CA19130/) | [GitHub Repository](https://github.com/Digital-AI-Finance/COST-Fintech-AI-in-Finance)

docs.title: Fintech and Artificial Intelligence in Finance
docs.text:
Towards a transparent financial industry

COST Action CA19130 (FinAI) was a four-year European research network (September 2020 - September 2024) dedicated to developing AI-based strategies for achieving transparency in finance. The Action brought together researchers, practitioners, and policymakers from 48 countries to address the challenges and opportunities of AI in the financial sector.

docs.title: Mission
docs.text:
Our mission was to create a pan-European research network that:

  • Develops blended approaches combining traditional and novel AI techniques for financial transparency
  • Investigates machine learning applications for fraud detection, risk management, and regulatory compliance
  • Promotes explainable AI (XAI) to ensure financial decisions can be understood and trusted
  • Creates open databases, frameworks, and best practices for the financial industry

docs.title: Action Overview
docs.text: Attribute Value Action Number CA19130 Title Fintech and Artificial Intelligence in Finance Duration 14 September 2020 - 13 September 2024 Status Completed Countries 48 (39 COST members + 9 international partners) Researchers 426 Working Groups 3 Grant Periods 5 Total Budget EUR 963,654

docs.title: Blockchain and Digital Assets
docs.text: Investigating transparency in cryptocurrencies, NFTs, ICOs, and decentralized finance (DeFi) platforms.

docs.title: Explainable AI in Finance
docs.text: Making black-box machine learning models interpretable for credit scoring, risk assessment, and investment decisions.

docs.title: Investment Performance Transparency
docs.text: Evaluating and communicating investment product performance, including ESG criteria and sustainable investments.

docs.title: Fraud Detection and Risk Management
docs.text: Applying AI/ML techniques for detecting financial fraud, money laundering, and predicting operational risks.

docs.title: What is COST?
docs.text: COST (European Cooperation in Science and Technology) is a funding organization for research and innovation networks. These networks, called COST Actions, offer an open space for collaboration among scientists across Europe and beyond.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Bottom-up approach: Scientists define research agendas
  • Networking focus: Funding for meetings, not direct research
  • Inclusiveness: Open to all research domains
  • Career development: Support for early-career researchers

docs.title: COST Actions
docs.text:
COST Actions are collaborative networks lasting 4 years that:

  • Connect researchers across Europe and internationally
  • Foster interdisciplinary collaboration
  • Support early-career investigators
  • Bridge academia and industry
  • Influence policy through evidence-based research

docs.title: Funding Mechanism
docs.text:
COST provides funding for:

Activity Description Meetings Workshops, conferences, MC meetings Training Schools Intensive courses for early-career researchers STSMs Short-Term Scientific Missions (research visits) Virtual Mobility Remote collaboration grants ITC Grants Conference support for ITC country researchers Dissemination Publications, websites, outreach

docs.title: ITC Countries
docs.text: Inclusiveness Target Countries (ITCs) are COST member countries with lower research capacity. COST Actions are encouraged to include researchers from these countries.

docs.title: Current ITC Countries
docs.text: Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, Greece, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Moldova, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Turkey, Ukraine

docs.title: ITC Benefits
docs.text:
• Priority for STSM grants
  • Dedicated ITC Conference Grants
  • Representation targets in leadership

docs.title: CA19130 and COST
docs.text:
COST Action CA19130 exemplified COST values by:

Inclusiveness

  • 48 participating countries
  • Strong ITC representation (50%+ of participants)
  • Diverse disciplinary backgrounds

Networking

  • 52 meetings across Europe
  • 7 training schools
  • 27 STSMs enabling researcher exchange

Impact

  • 1,000+ collaborative publications
  • Policy influence on AI regulation
  • Lasting professional networks

docs.title: How to Participate
docs.text:
While CA19130 has concluded, new COST Actions are regularly launched. To participate:

  1. Join an existing Action: Browse open Actions
  2. Propose a new Action: Submit during Open Calls
  3. Attend events: Many Action events welcome external participants

docs.title: Memorandum of Understanding Objectives
docs.text: The COST Action CA19130 was established with six core objectives as defined in the Memorandum of Understanding:

docs.title: Objective 1: Blended Approaches
docs.text:
Develop blended approaches combining traditional and AI techniques for evaluating innovative financial services

  • Integrate classical financial analysis with machine learning
  • Create hybrid models that leverage both interpretability and predictive power
  • Establish methodologies for comparing traditional vs. AI approaches

Achievement: 100% - Multiple frameworks developed and published

docs.title: Objective 2: Machine Learning Applications
docs.text:
Apply ML for prediction, fraud detection, and money laundering prevention

Research focus areas: - Credit risk scoring with explainable models - Real-time fraud detection systems - Anti-money laundering (AML) pattern recognition - Market manipulation detection

Achievement: 100% - Extensive publications and tools developed

docs.title: Objective 3: Open Databases
docs.text:
Create open databases for ICOs, crowdfunding, and financial products

Deliverables created: - Pre-ICO documentation database - Crowdfunding platform features database - Financial time series repository - ESG data collection

Achievement: 100% - All databases completed and made available

docs.title: Objective 4: Transparency Frameworks
docs.text:
Develop frameworks for AI model transparency in financial services

Key outputs: - XAI best practices guide - Model documentation standards - Audit frameworks for AI systems - Regulatory compliance checklists

Achievement: 95% - Comprehensive frameworks delivered

docs.title: Objective 5: Risk Assessment
docs.text:
Create methodologies for assessing AI-related risks in finance

Research areas: - Model risk quantification - Algorithmic bias detection - Systemic risk from AI adoption - Cybersecurity in AI systems

Achievement: 90% - Major methodological advances

docs.title: Objective 6: Knowledge Dissemination
docs.text:
Disseminate knowledge through training, publications, and policy engagement

Activities: - Training schools and workshops - Academic publications - Policy briefs and white papers - Industry partnerships

Achievement: 100% - Extensive dissemination achieved

docs.title: COST Action CA19130: FinAI
docs.text: Fintech and Artificial Intelligence in Finance - Towards a transparent financial industry

docs.title: Background
docs.text: The financial industry has undergone significant transformation with the advent of artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies. However, the opacity of many AI systems poses challenges for regulation, trust, and adoption. COST Action CA19130 was established to address these challenges by building a pan-European research network focused on transparency in AI-driven finance.

docs.title: Scientific Scope
docs.text:
The Action brought together researchers from diverse disciplines including:

  • Computer Science: Machine learning, deep learning, explainable AI
  • Finance: Risk management, portfolio optimization, trading systems
  • Economics: Market microstructure, behavioral finance, regulatory economics
  • Law: Financial regulation, data protection, algorithmic accountability
  • Statistics: Time series analysis, Bayesian methods, causal inference

docs.title: Research Approach
docs.text:
Our research followed a multi-pronged approach:

  1. Empirical Analysis: Studying real-world applications of AI in finance
  2. Methodological Development: Creating new techniques for model transparency
  3. Policy Research: Informing regulatory frameworks for AI in finance
  4. Technology Transfer: Bridging academia and industry practices

docs.title: Key Research Areas
docs.text: Area Focus Outcomes Blockchain Transparency Analyzing cryptocurrency markets, ICOs, DeFi Fraud detection models, risk frameworks Explainable AI Making ML models interpretable XAI toolkits, best practices Investment Analytics Performance evaluation, ESG Stress testing frameworks Risk Management Operational risk, credit risk Early warning systems

docs.title: COST Action CA19130 Timeline (2020-2024)
docs.text:
September 2020 Action Launch

  • Action officially started on 14 September 2020
  • Initial network of 33 COST member countries
  • 63 Management Committee members
  • Grant Holder: Zurich University of Applied Sciences (ZHAW)

November 2020 Grant Period 1 Begins

  • First funding period activated
  • Working Groups established
  • Initial research agenda defined
  • First virtual meetings organized (COVID-19 pandemic)

2021 Network Expansion

  • Network grew to 49 countries
  • First training schools organized
  • STSM program launched
  • Virtual Mobility grants introduced
  • 21 meetings organized

November 2021 Grant Period 2

  • Continued growth and consolidation
  • Expanded industry partnerships
  • Major publication outputs begin

June 2022 Grant Holder Transition

  • Grant Holder changed to Bern University of Applied Sciences
  • Seamless administrative transition
  • Grant Period 3 begins

August 2022 Midterm Review

  • Successful midterm evaluation
  • 76-100% achievement on all objectives
  • Network grown to 260 researchers
  • Positive rapporteur assessment

November 2022 Grant Period 4

  • Peak activity period
  • 150+ events organized
  • Second-largest COST Action by country participation
  • Major deliverables completed

2023 Full Momentum

  • 6,000+ event participants
  • 10,000+ citations milestone
  • Training schools across Europe
  • Strong industry engagement

November 2023 Grant Period 5 (Final)

  • Final funding period
  • Focus on deliverable completion
  • Legacy planning and sustainability
  • Knowledge transfer activities

September 2024 Action Completion

  • Successfully completed on 13 September 2024
  • All 15 deliverables achieved
  • 420 researchers from 55 countries globally
  • Lasting network established

docs.title: Dissemination Activities
docs.text: COST Action CA19130 conducted extensive dissemination activities to share research findings with academic and non-academic audiences.

docs.title: Communication Strategy
docs.text:
Our dissemination strategy targeted multiple audiences:

  • Academic Community: Through peer-reviewed publications, conferences, and workshops
  • Industry Stakeholders: Through policy briefs, industry events, and partnerships
  • General Public: Through media appearances, popular science articles, and social media

docs.title: Publications
docs.text: Over 1,000 peer-reviewed publications were produced by Action members, disseminating research findings globally.

docs.title: Media Presence
docs.text: Action members appeared in various media outlets discussing fintech, AI in finance, and related topics.

docs.title: Social Media

docs.title: Outreach Events
docs.text:

  • Public lectures and seminars
  • Policy briefings in Brussels
  • Media interviews and press releases

docs.title: Mobility Grants
docs.text: COST Action CA19130 supported researcher mobility through Short-Term Scientific Missions (STSMs), Virtual Mobility grants, and ITC Conference Grants.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
27 STSMs

EUR 60,082.00 STSM Funding

38 Virtual Mobility Grants

docs.title: Short-Term Scientific Missions (STSMs)
docs.text: STSMs enable researchers to visit a host institution in another country for a period of 5-180 days. These missions foster collaboration, knowledge transfer, and joint research.

docs.title: Virtual Mobility Grants
docs.text: Virtual Mobility grants support remote collaboration activities, enabling researchers to work together without physical travel.

docs.title: ITC Conference Grants
docs.text: ITC Conference Grants support researchers from Inclusiveness Target Countries (ITCs) to participate in conferences.

docs.title: ITC Conference Grants
docs.text: ITC Conference Grants support researchers from Inclusiveness Target Countries (ITCs) to participate in major conferences, presenting their research and networking with the international community.

docs.title: About ITC Conference Grants
docs.text: COST Inclusiveness Target Countries (ITCs) are countries with lower participation in COST Actions. Supporting researchers from these countries is a key priority for COST.

docs.title: ITC Countries
docs.text: Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, Greece, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Moldova, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Turkey, and Ukraine.

docs.title: Grant Details
docs.text:
ITC Conference Grants cover:

  • Conference registration fees
  • Travel costs
  • Accommodation expenses

See Mobility Overview for more information on all mobility support available.

docs.title: Prof. Jorg Osterrieder
docs.text:
Bern University of Applied Sciences, Switzerland

Prof. Jorg Osterrieder served as the Action Chair of COST Action CA19130 throughout its entire duration (2020-2024).

docs.title: Responsibilities
docs.text:
As Action Chair, Prof. Osterrieder was responsible for:

  • Strategic leadership and direction of the Action
  • Coordination of Working Groups and activities
  • Representation of the Action to COST Association
  • Oversight of budget and resource allocation
  • Facilitation of network development and collaboration

docs.title: Grant Holder Institution
docs.text:
The Action was hosted by two institutions during its duration:

Period Institution GP1-GP2 (Nov 2020 - May 2022) Zurich University of Applied Sciences (ZHAW) GP3-GP5 (Jun 2022 - Sep 2024) Bern University of Applied Sciences (BFH)

docs.title: Additional Roles
docs.text: Prof. Poti also served as the Scientific Advisory Board Coordinator from August 2022.

docs.title: Working Group Leaders
docs.text: The three Working Groups of COST Action CA19130 were led by distinguished researchers in their respective fields.

docs.title: WG1: Transparency in FinTech
docs.text:
Leader: Prof. Wolfgang Hardle

Investigating transparency in blockchain, cryptocurrencies, NFTs, digital assets, and innovative financial services using ML methods. Focus on prediction of operational fragility and fraudulent behavior.

Members at End of Action: 277

Key Topics:

  • Blockchain
  • Cryptocurrencies
  • NFTs
  • Digital Assets
  • Fraud Detection

docs.title: WG2: Transparent vs Black Box Decision-Support Models
docs.text:
Leader: Dr. Petre Lameski

Development of conceptual and methodological tools for making black-box models transparent or interpretable/explainable. Focus on XAI approaches, credit risk modeling, and ML model robustness.

Members at End of Action: 248

Key Topics:

  • Explainable AI
  • Credit Risk
  • Model Interpretability
  • Decision Support
  • ML Robustness

docs.title: WG3: Investment Product Performance Transparency
docs.text:
Leader: Prof. Peter Schwendner

Investment product performance evaluation, sustainable investments, stress testing AI/ML models, digital asset investments, performance attribution, and false discovery rate reduction.

Members at End of Action: 218

Key Topics:

  • Investment Performance
  • ESG
  • Stress Testing
  • Digital Assets
  • Performance Attribution

docs.title: Management Committee
docs.text: The Management Committee of COST Action CA19130 consisted of 70 members representing COST member countries.

docs.title: Role of the MC
docs.text:
The Management Committee is the decision-making body of a COST Action, responsible for:

  • Approving the Action's work plan and budget
  • Monitoring progress and achievements
  • Making strategic decisions
  • Electing the Action Chair and Vice-Chair

docs.title: MC Composition
docs.text:
Each participating country can have up to 2 MC members plus 2 substitutes.

See MC Members by Country for the full list.

docs.title: ITC Country Members
docs.text:
Members from COST Inclusiveness Target Countries (ITCs).

0 members from ITC countries participated in COST Action CA19130.

docs.title: ITC Countries Represented
docs.text: Country Members

docs.title: About ITCs
docs.text: Inclusiveness Target Countries are countries with lower participation in COST Actions. Supporting researchers from these countries is a key priority for COST.

docs.title: Member Profiles
docs.text: Browse individual profiles for all 425 COST Action CA19130 members.

docs.title: Midterm Review
docs.text: COST Action CA19130 underwent its midterm review in August 2022.

docs.title: Review Outcomes
docs.text: The Action achieved 76-100% completion on all MoU objectives at midterm.

docs.title: Achievements by Midterm
docs.text:
• Network grown to 260 researchers from 42 countries
  • 15+ meetings organized
  • 9 STSMs completed
  • Multiple publications produced

docs.title: Recommendations
docs.text:
The review panel recommended continued focus on:

  • Expanding network to additional countries
  • Increasing ITC participation
  • Enhancing dissemination activities

docs.title: Post-Midterm Actions
docs.text:
Following the review, the Action:

  • Transitioned grant holder to Bern University of Applied Sciences
  • Launched additional training schools
  • Expanded virtual mobility program

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text: Frequently asked questions about the Action.

docs.title: What is COST Action CA19130?
docs.text: COST Action CA19130 'Fintech and Artificial Intelligence in Finance' was a European research network focused on transparency in the financial industry.

docs.title: When did the Action run?
docs.text: The Action ran from November 2020 to September 2024.

docs.title: How many researchers participated?
docs.text: Over 420 researchers from 48 countries participated in the Action.

docs.title: How could I join the Action?
docs.text: The Action has now concluded. Future COST Actions can be joined through the COST e-services portal.

docs.title: What is a Working Group?
docs.text: Working Groups are thematic sub-groups within a COST Action that focus on specific research areas.

docs.title: What funding was available?
docs.text: COST provided funding for meetings, training schools, STSMs, virtual mobility, and dissemination activities.

docs.title: What is an STSM?
docs.text: A Short-Term Scientific Mission (STSM) is a research visit to a host institution in another country.

docs.title: Where can I find publications?
docs.text: See the Publications section for Action research outputs.

docs.title: Are datasets available?

Investigating transparency in blockchain, cryptocurrencies, NFTs, and digital assets. Research focuses on fraud detection using ML and operational fragility prediction.

  • Crypto exchange transparency

docs.title: WG2: Transparent versus Black Box Decision-Support Models
Overview
docs.text:
Leader: Prof Petre Lameski (Ss. Cyril and Methodius University)

Participants: 254 researchers from 40+ countries

Making black-box machine learning models transparent and interpretable. Focus on Explainable AI (XAI), credit risk modeling, fairness in ML, and model robustness.

docs.title: Research Focus
docs.text:
• Explainable AI (XAI) methods
  • Credit risk scoring transparency
  • Model interpretability techniques
  • Fairness in machine learning
  • Algorithmic bias detection
  • Model robustness and reliability
  • Feature importance analysis
  • Counterfactual explanations

docs.title: Transparent vs Black Box Decision-Support Models
docs.text: Development of conceptual and methodological tools for making black-box models transparent or interpretable/explainable. Focus on XAI approaches, credit risk modeling, and ML model robustness.

docs.title: WG3: Transparency into Investment Product Performance
Overview
docs.text:
Leader: Prof Peter Schwendner (ZHAW Zurich)

Participants: 223 researchers from 40+ countries

Evaluating and communicating investment product performance to clients. Research on ESG criteria, sustainable investments, stress testing AI/ML models, and digital asset investments.

docs.title: Research Focus
docs.text:
• Investment performance analytics
  • ESG (Environmental, Social, Governance) metrics
  • Sustainable investment evaluation
  • Portfolio risk transparency
  • Digital asset investment strategies
  • Performance attribution analysis
  • False discovery rate control
  • Factor model transparency

docs.title: Key Deliverables
docs.text:
• D5: Backtesting Framework
  • D9: Risk Management Handbook
  • D10: Digital Asset Risk Position Paper
  • D12: AI Models for Network Analysis
